summary: It's the summer of 1983, and precocious 17-year-old Elio Perlman is spending the days with his family at their 17th-century villa in Lombardy, Italy. He soon meets Oliver, a handsome doctoral student who's working as an intern for Elio's father. Amid the sun-drenched splendor of their surroundings, Elio and Oliver discover the heady beauty of awakening desire over the course of a summer that will alter their lives forever.

reviews.content: In all honesty, this movie might be the next step for Kany* W*st after the 21 Jump Street debacle. However, I am not him. Oliver is as despicable as he is in this movie and in real life. At least he played a role true to himself? The age gap is problematic and you know what? I'm gonna say it. I don't care that the culture and laws might be different in Italy. They're 17 and 24 and it's gross. Not only that, but Elio and Oliver only want one thing and it's so boring.

This movie seemed fine but it was low quality. I actually almost puked when he "did" things to a peach alone in his bedroom. It was predictable but uncomfortable. I cringed and with the uncomfortable zestiness. On the other hand the set and surroundings were absolutely beautiful and made me want to move to Italy.  The biggest plot twist was when the older guy ended up getting married to a girl.

This movie is one of the best movies I have ever seen. The ending scene left a pit in my stomach and really moved me. When watching this film I felt something in me that I haven't felt in a long time. The pastel colors in the Italian town with such utter sadness hidden underneath is truly breathtaking.

Personally, Call Me By Your Name provides a feeling like no other film does and perhaps ever will. Not only are the characters enticing but the cinematography itself, although to some it appears as "choppy", to me, it adds so much more to the story. I could and will watch this film over and over again.

Not to single out this particular premise, but films revolving around gay couples have been terrific over the last decade or so. There was a spark when 2005's Brokeback Mountain was released, which eventually brought us to foreign films like Blue Is the Warmest Colour being nominated for a Golden Globe or Moonlight winning best picture at the Oscars. Call Me by Your Name is the latest film to probably receive many nominations in the coming months, and believe me, the praise is not false. Being a fan of 2015's A Bigger Splash, I was looking forward to Luca Guadagnino's follow-up feature film, and I believe this to be an improvement in the best ways. Exploring the hardships of life and what it means to just kick back and relax every now and then, Call Me by Your Name is a film that's been sticking with me since my viewing of it. While it admittedly won't be able to draw in everyone to the theatres, here is why I believe this to be a fantastic, award-worthy picture.

Written by James Ivory and directed by Luca Guadagnino, Call Me by Your Name follows a family that lets Oliver, an older graduate student, live in their home for the summer. While this is a common thing, what's not too common is that Elio, their son, will eventually grow romantic feelings toward this man, convincing him to become his lover for the summer. From the age gap between them and having to hide it from the family, their situation isn't an easy one, nor will it be for some audience members, but it really is a wonderful story. This is easily a story that could've stirred up controversy if it hadn't been done with taste, and because of how it was made, I just couldn't take my eyes off the screen. This was made entirely possible by the incredibly devoted performances by Timothée Chalamet and Armie Hammer.

Hammer has had his ups and downs through the years, appearing in Oscar-winning films as well as some of the worst films of the year, so his performance here was the most shocking to me. Yes, he's been talent in nearly everything he's been in, but he really gave his all in this performance and I honestly don't think he'll ever be better than he was in Call Me by Your Name. On the other hand, young Chalamet has a very bright future ahead of him. Being a relatively new actor, his chemistry with Hammer was impeccably astounding. Their relationship took a while to grow on me, but once it completely won me over, I found myself wondering if there was anything to really complain about.

If I had to complain about anything, it would be in its extreme pressure to try your patience. There are very long sequences of silence, making you relax and take in either a romantic moment or the scenery around them, which I also found poetic at the same time, so I actually have trouble coming up with issues, but I have to admit that I did find the movie slow at times. Yes, it's meant to be slow, which is why that complaint isn't exactly valid, but I just have to be honest.

In the end, this is a truly remarkable piece of dramatic filmmaking and there are some very memorable scenes that keep replaying themselves in my head. One scene in particular that involves Elio and his father Mr. Perlman (played magnificently by Michael Stuhlbarg) toward the end had me in tears. From the brilliantly written screenplay, to the poetic cinematography, to the terrifically calm direction, Call Me by Your Name isn't a movie that I would send the average moviegoer out to see, but if you're a hardcore film fan, I think you'll end up loving this movie.
Would be a perfect movie if there wasn't a minor involved. Appreciate the cinematography but know there was absolutely no reason for one of the characters to be a child.
I fell in love with this movie as it was so romantic and happy but they managed to get a feeling of melancholy in the background
El único amor que quiero

Nothing wrong with the casting, locations or acting, but the plot is paper thin, and I can't help but wonder what the response to this film would be like if it was centered on a hetero love story. Skirting over the controversial age difference, there is no real build up in tension to the main relationship, the plot unfolds exactly how you expect it to after 5 minutes of watching the film, and some of the lines are completely bizarre. If I just wanted to look at nice Italian scenery I would buy some postcards.

Timotheé Chalamet and Armie Hammer star in Luca Guadagnino's moving adaptation of Andre Aciman's bestselling novel. Dazzling performances and ravishing visuals propel ‘Call Me by Your Name' into its place as one of 2017's best films.

Timotheé Chalamet stars as Elio, an artistic 17-year-old who spends his summer in the picturesque landscapes of Northern Italy, transcribing music and hanging out with his friends. Being on the cusp of adulthood, Elio also spends his days flirting with his friend Marzia (Esther Garrel) and experiencing love for the first time. His mundane routine is interrupted when American student Oliver (played by Armie Hammer) arrives to work with Elio's father (‘A Serious Man star Michael Stuhlbarg). As the summer progresses, Elio and Oliver form a fervent love, developing a passionate bond that will forever impact their lives.

American singer/songwriter Sufjan Stevens composed two original songs (‘Mystery of Love' and ‘Visions of Gideon') and provides a remix of his own song ‘Futile Devices'. Stevens' music accompanies a variety of songs ranging from classical music pieces to 80s pop songs. The mix of musical genres effortlessly compliments Sayombhu Mukdeeprom's cinematography that echoes the visuals of Joe Wright's 2007 drama ‘Atonement'. Luca Guadagnino miraculously brings together first-class filmmaking to create a delicate, yet heart-breaking story with a poetic story at its centre.

Timotheé Chalamet and Armie Hammer bring their A games to ‘Call Me by Your Name', both providing Oscar-worthy performances fuelled by intense chemistry between them. Chalamet's performance encompasses Elio's intelligence and artistic flair, while Hammer brings Oliver's suave and breezy persona to the screen. Michael Stuhlbarg gives a wonderful performance as does Amira Casar and Esther Garrel. Stuhlbarg's standout moment comes when he gives a touching monologue to Elio after Oliver's departure and ‘to make yourself feel nothing so as to not feel anything' is a waste. However, Chalamet proves himself as a talented performer during the final scene as the credits roll beside him. His performance is a mix of discovering yourself and being a teenager, while also discovering love and how it feels. Both of which tie into some of ‘Call Me by Your Name's complex themes of heartbreak, identity and coming-of-age.

‘Call Me by Your Name' delves into intricate themes like the joy of love and with it the pain of loneliness that comes when you are without your significant other. The film also quite obviously explores themes of sexuality, and covers Elio's journey of self-discovery, an example being the infamous peach scene. Most likely unbeknownst to most of the film's audience is the fact that ‘Call Me by Your Name' is the final instalment in Luca Guadagnino's Desire trilogy. The triad of films is also comprised of 2009's ‘I Am Love', starring Tilda Swinton and 2015's ‘A Bigger Splash', starring Ralph Fiennes, Dakota Johnson, and Matthias Schoenaerts alongside Swinton.

Luca Guadagnino brings a passionate love story to the screen bound alongside a delicate coming of age tale. Brilliant craftmanship and a remarkable screenplay by James Ivory, come together to create a mesmerising viewing experience. The film is an elegant adaptation of Andre Aciman's novel, and it's uncommon to find a film as delicate as this one. Chalamet and Hammer give career-defining performances, never faltering across the 130-minute runtime.

This is outstanding.  I can't believe that it took me 5 years to watch it.  Heartfelt, warm and realistic.  Being that this was in 1983, and in Italy, this story progressed exactly as it should have, and how rare is that?

Timothy Shalamet delivers in iconic performance of the character that we didn't need. But that we unfortunately got, I do not think that this movie is a bad movie. I think this movie actually touches on a lot of subjects that people need to talk about, but I also do not think that this movie deserves all the recognition that it did get. This movie is about basically a child molester, because he was a grown adult, having sexual relations with a child. And then, at the end of the day that the was so into this man that he was having sexual and inside of fruit. So at the end of the day, I'm not quite sure exactly how I truly feel about this movie, but I think this moving is something to touch on as an adult and realize that this is not great. But also, the only thing that I can rate is Timothée Chalamet's performance as this character, though was over the top and he did a wonderful job for trying something that I would not have been comfortable doing.

This is a simple and patient movie and audiences need to be exactly that as they wait through the little gestures and small touches that characterise the early days of a blossoming romance between 17-year-old Elio (Timothee Chalamet) and the older man (Armie Hammer) hired as his father's research assistant. The languid pacing suits the setting of a summer in in 1980s Italy and there are some lovely, deliberate and detailed touches in its symbolism, making it quite lovely in its commentary on the emotions of first love.

What in my opinion is wrong with "Call Me By Your Name" directed by Luca Guadagnino is the age of the actor Armie Hammer (in his 30s when shooting the movie), because he plays the role of a 24 year old boy, Oliver, having an affair with the 17 year old Elio (Timothée Chalamet): by no means Hammer can look like a 24 year old person, he just looks like a 30+ year old man, and this gives the story a creepy turn, as if a very conscious adult pedophile was grooming his new, innocent victim, with the even creepier approval of the minor's parents (the father's speech would have sounded magnificent instead if we had the right ages on the screen). 
I doubt that director Luca Guadagnino didn't have any 24 year old actor (or looking like one) available, so I really don't know what to make of this otherwise gorgeously made movie: an attempt to normalising pedophilia? 
Two actors looking like the novel indicated would have told the story of a genuine summer love; the way the movie looks instead doesn't feel right. With a different actor, I would have given 5 stars.
Having said that, Timothée Chalamet is exquisite. The ending scene with the close-up on his face while the music of Sufjan Stevens goes on is just sheer perfection. 
Note for the American audience: don't be shocked by the lack of moral disapproval from Italian movie-goers: in Italy the age of consent is 14.

A bit of a toad elevating moment, besides the age subject matter I gave it one star for the song and one star for Timothée's last scene. I really wanted to like this movie especially the way the critics where raving about it. Better luck next movie?

I'll never look at a peach the same way again. The cinematography is lovely but I can't get past the fact that this film is about a predator who grooms a young man. He's in a position of power. Romanticizing this is effed up. Just because it's a gay relationship doesn't make it okay.

This is a somewhat nostalgic (its set in 1983), fairly laid back feeling film, set during a summer holiday in Italy. The setting is lovely - it's only described as 'somewhere in Northern Italy' and there's some relatively thoughtful dialogue present, although there are some scenes when the characters don't talk too often. I also enjoyed the classical/instrumental music often played in the background, which gives it a somewhat dream-like/floaty feel or sense. I particularly liked the light piano tunes, which had a bit of an ethereal sense to them at times. The characters seem very thoughtful and it's quite an atmospheric film. I would recommend it, yes.

To each their own but this movie appeared very hollow to me.  The chemistry between Armie Hammer and Timothy Chamalet is . . . not there.  They look just like two straight guys making out and it is painful to watch indeed.  I just could not connect to this.

The whole thing feels like a hazy daydream. A sun soaked Italian villa and town filled with beautiful people in swim wear 70% of the time...who wouldn't want to fuck everyone? So much of it feels surreal, but in the right ways. Timothee Chalomet and Armie Hammer both are naturally actors that are tough to like for me (for VERY different reasons mind you), but their work in Call Me By Your Name is pretty undeniably great. Much of the conflict in the movie is implied. It's legitimate conflict at that - acceptance of homosexuality in the 80s was obviously very different than it is now - but the amount to which this is only implied had sort of had a reverse effect on me where it seemed like the movie was overconsumed with what boiled down to "rich white people problems." That coupled with Elio's (Chalomet) surprisingly indulgent and accepting family simply turns this into a summer romance movie. A very good summer romance movie...but something I truly only have so much patience for. Sufjan Stevens' music that's included is a great analog for the movie. Sufjan's music is great albeit being fairly twee. So unless I'm really there for it in the moment, there's only so much I can endure without grumbling to myself "Okay, come on guy."
Although the ensemble offers courageous, powerful performances, and the movie is wonderfully shot, the pace of the movie is a little too leisurely in my opinion.
Love my way… watching this movie <3

A beautiful summer love story, with amazing settings. The script is beautifully written and has some very heartfelt scenes that will make you cry. Chalamet and Hammer's performances are nothing but espetacular, their vulnerability is everything. Not to mention the director who absolutely nailed it making us feel as if we were experiencing every moment with the characters. Highly recommend it.

A few minutes ago I finished watching the movie and I'm (positively) impacted. What a beautiful, beautiful love story. Timothee and Armie were incredible, but the scene that touched me the most - and, I suspect, the one that will linger in my memory - is the monologue of Michael Stuhlbarg's character. What text. What an emotional scene. I can barely remember her without tearing up my eyes. The most touching thing is that the story takes place in the 1980s, at a time when the theme the film deals with was not so addressed and well accepted among society and, especially, among families. And that's what makes the scene even more emotional, as Elio's father was completely selfless and ahead of his time. It certainly has become one of my all time favorite movies.
Call Me by Your Name

AHHHHHH! The vibe is four-wheel drive and will roll on you with no hesitation. Be prepared to feel nostalgic for a place and time that you never lived for many hours after the movie.

Whoa, boy, this is gonna be tough! For the fact that I love lesbian movies and how much I love women but for a movie about g*y men, this is something I'm not broken into. But for Call Me by Your Name, I have to come out by watching it and review it to give my thoughts about it and just to make it clear, I am a hetrosexual, I love women because they're sexy and also, there's nothing wrong with g*y people. I'm not a h******bic and I am not a h**o. Now with that clears it, let's get with it. A Jewish Italo-French young man named Elio played by Timothée Chalamet lives with his parents in rural Northern Italy. Elio's father who is professor of archaeology, invites Oliver played by Armie Hammer, to live with the family over the summer. Elio spends much of the summer reading, playing piano, and hanging out with his childhood friends and of course, the gay romance begins. As I am going through this like I always do and so far, so good, I really enjoyed it. The story keeps you going and leaving you wondering what's going to happen next. The acting in this is brilliant, you can't really go wrong. Armie Hammer and Timothée Chalamet have good chemistry together in this movie. So as far as I enjoyed Call Me by Your Name I still love lesbian films with g*y women but there's nothing wrong with checking this one out that is if you're interested. It's almost like I'm watching a foreign film with different language and subtitles so I can understand what the people are saying. Some of them are speaking different language and I get where this is going. So in all, I enjoyed this one. It had great acting, great story, great atmosphere and great shots. Even if you're gay or not I'd still say check this one out. I know I have. Oh, also there's a tribute at the end of the credits which says "In loving memory of Bill Paxton". So yeah, that is something. Call Me by Your Name is a great coming-of-age romantic drama.
A gay masterpiece ok I'll go with that I love it and I love you too.

Well it came with such hype; but I found it a very slow burn at the outset, and unnecessarily so. The film seemed to be very long. I'm not sure Arnie Hammer was the right choice of character, his brash Americanness jarred and made him largely two dimensional throughout the film. The recurring 'later,' was quite tiresome, and detracted from the smouldering that could have made the film much more interesting. There is a thin Jewish line running through the film; it was not a problem, but I don't think it added anything to the film. The narrative seemed to have a number of unnecessary back stories, which did nothing, the relationships with the women, perhaps helped set the tone of the time, but was inapposite. The session with the father at the end was nice, but not really very natural; there was no real build up to it, the father in many ways seemed somewhat distanced from Elio. The (colour) cast of the film was a little peculiar too; perhaps the bright Italian sun, but it was almost faded Kodachrome at times, and this did nothing for the film either. The continuous clumsy smoking (rarely seen in cinema today), might have been authentic, but it did not really have any point either, as it could have done. James Ivory has made some amazing films, but this one was not one of them. I suspect he is getting a bit old now -- as we all do. I was glad I saw this film, and I really wanted to like it, but it didn't hang together well enough for me.

i liked the way how the relationship starts but the difference of age between elio and oliver seems awful to me

Okay, we have two brilliant performances here: Timothée Chalamet and Michael Stuhlbarg. They save this movie from being a total catastrophe. Chalamet has more chemistry with Esther Garrel than with Armie Hammer (the focus of the film is on the romance between Chalamet and Hammer), the script seems adapted from a fanfic written on Wattpad, Armie Hammer constantly tries to seduce the public thinking he's a younger Brad Pitt, the film is absurdly long and Chalamet's and Hammer's characters physical age bothered me. They don't look like a couple, they look like they're uncle and nephew. Oh, and a personal note that constantly removed me from the film: Chalamet is identical to Charles Leclerc!
Best drama movie of all time.

The movie takes the viewer for an emotional journey that one cannot resist. Even though there is not much happening, the tender sensuality of the movie keeps you totally gripped. The incredibly vibrant tension of young enchantment and desire evolving througout the movie make up for a somewhat pretentious beginning where the couple of first dialogues are a slightly stiff and forcefully intelectual. Italian sun that paint the scenes creates impression of lightness and carelessness, however the story is inseparably beautiful and sad. The movie reaches its splendor with an inconspicuous scene, where Elio's dad talks to him. Impressively wise words from a man aware of the fact that the most intense days in his life are already over.
Very beautiful scenery, amazing story and good actors. I like it so much!

I had my expectations way up after reading so many rave reviews about this movie. But it was not only NOT a masterpiece, it was entirely vapid. The story is non existent, the dialogue is non sensical and the supposed romance was entirely absent. This movie is about two gay guys in the 80s who get horny for each other while one is a summer guest at the family house of the other. Both characters were boring and unlikable and there were a number of tasteless and vulgar sexual scenes. Timothee Chalamet's acting is average and uninteresting - Armie Hammer was fine but didn't have much of a script to work with. It must be terrible to be an actor and have to take parts like this. I would also add as a side note, Chalamet has the most scrawny unattractive body I've ever seen and was shirtless through most of it - what a turn off!

I could not take my eyes off the screen while watching Call Me by Your Name. This beautiful movie is filled with dreamy romance. Call Me by Your Name is a coming of age film that follows Elio and Oliver's undeniable romance in Italy during the 1980s. 

I praise Luca Guadagnino's intricate mise en scene compliments for making the whole movie flow as a fantasy. The pastel tinted lighting ties in the watcher to create a dreamlike feeling. The lighting easily pairs with Crema's scenic nature within the film. The lighting and scenic nature really emphasize the feeling of an Italian summer. I felt just starry eyed viewing the film.
 
The placement of tasteful fruits, especially peaches, had me in awe while viewing the film. The peach scene signifies Elios realization of his sexuality which is a defining moment in the movie. Elio confesses that he loves Oliver right after his curiosity with the peach. I feel like the placement of a peach in such a vulnerable moment with Elio really leaves the watcher with a sense that the film is a lustful fantasy. 

Sexual desire is not only shown through fruits, but also through water. There are multiple scenes including bodies of water. Elio and Oliver bike to a discrete pond, and splash in the pool while talking. In both instances they end up admiring each other's bodies which creates this strong attraction between Oliver and Elio. I really felt as if the desirable tension between Elio and Oliver throughout these scenes really emphasized the dreamy vibe developed in Call Me by Your Name.
5.0/10 — "Poor"/"Inferior"/"Amateurish"

Luca Guadagnino's sumptous tale of desire set in a beautiful rural Tuscany village focuses on the relationship between Armie Hammer's US intern and the multilingual son of his host, brilliantly played by Timothee Chalmet. With a wonderful supporting cast, (most notably Michael Stuhlbarg, the father everyone needs) Guadagnino soaks you perfectly in the setting, making you totally believe in the characters and the story. With a sequel incoming, it will be very interesting to see where they go, because the ending to Call Me By Your Name is perfect.

Pretty shots, unique cinematography and aesthetic stylized scenery of 80s Italian summer in the province are no way near enough to make a movie enjoyable or to sugarcoat the fact that this movie romanticized an incredibly creepy 30 something year old groomer and a sexually active teenager "falling in love". No matter how pretty of a face he has, that does not negate the fact that this is incredibly predatory. Not to mention the overused milked dry trope of having straight sex to test the waters (because gays apparently can never realize they're gay without having to experiment with a member of the opposite sex first) or that we can't have a happy ending, though in this context I'm glad they didn't end up with each other, I just hoped the predator would die at least, but oh well.

A must watch

Elio's parents starred alongside Chalamet and Hammer as their performance was impeccable. Call Me by Your Name tells a beautiful, heart-wrenching love story about two people loving each other and living in the moment. Rather than being a political commentary about the social climate of the time, Call Me by Your Name instead chooses to center its story firmly around the two lead characters and their eventual relationship. I feel this plays strongly to its advantage as it in no way feels preachy. Rather, it feels as though the filmmakers, who adapted this screenplay from a book of the same name, truly wanted to tell a genuine love story. This film has so many great scenes of dialogue and the imagery is alluring. In many ways this film immerses you into its story with great writing and strong performances, especially from Timothèe Chalamet, and a delightful soundtrack. It's story is also very grounded which I always appreciate. My only minor criticism is that some moments in the film didn't quite pack the emotional punch that I wanted them too, but again, a very minor criticism for a film that I thoroughly enjoyed.

If you want something pretty to look at, this movie will surely deliver. The cinematography and color theory in this film feels like a towel fresh out of the dryer, its comforting and warm and really makes you yearn for summer in a way I didn't expect. Although the movie is beautiful in that sense, it lacks in the actual story. I read the book before viewing the movie and was surprised with how much was left out of the film! The movie really only tells the story of Elio and Oliver on what feels like a surface level, whereas the book really gets into the characters internal struggles and how that effects their dynamic. This movie feels like a classic case of the book being better than the movie. If you want to watch CMBYN and enjoy it to the fullest extent, I'd recommend reading the book before hand so that you can really enjoy the story its trying to tell.

This film takes you to a calm and peaceful state of mind. The combination of the scenery, the music, and the performances all come together to create a beautiful film. The storyline is slightly choppy and not quite straight forward, but I think this is the beauty of the film. There is not much dialogue between the two main characters, Elio and Oliver. This creates lots of tension between the two characters from very early on in the film. As it progresses however, we begin to realize that this tension is not only just awkward silences of two people meeting for the first time, but it becomes more of a sexual tension that grows larger and larger. The scene sequence when Elio volunteers to go into town with Oliver is when we start to feel this type of tension. Right before they leave Elio sits on the side of the pool as Oliver swims. As they plan to go Oliver says something and Elio mocks him in an odd voice, this reveals that Elio is so much younger and more naive than Oliver, as their love story unfolds, we see this become more evident. They arrive into town and Oliver goes to buy a pack of cigarettes revealing his maturity. The way these two dance around each other for the majority of the film is frustrating yet amazing. Overall it is an incredible film and I would recommend it to anyone.

A cinematic masterpiece, with a beautiful portrayal of love is the best way to sum up this work of art. The film immediately places you "somewhere in Northern Italy," and for the rest of the film you feel like you are right there in Italy, observing Elio and Oliver's blossoming romance. The performances from Timothee Chalamet and Armie Hammer really sell the love their characters have for each other during every scene. The relationship between Elio and Oliver seems truly authentic. Their shared awkwardness makes the relationship look real and spontaneous. This  is significant, as most romance movies do the exact opposite by shying away from realism. Possibly the best thing this film does is its use of non-diegetic sound to replace dialogue in a scene. The music in the film tells us more about the characters in that moment than any piece of dialogue ever could. Futile Devices plays during a scene early in the film, which corresponds to the early days of Elio and Oliver's relationship. The scene can be depicted as Elio missing Oliver, but also longing for something so much more, as in this scene Elio knows he's in love with Oliver. None of this is said or told to the audience, but conveyed through a short montage with just the sound of music playing over it. This film is important due to its representation of the LGBTQ+ community. Elio and Oliver are two men madly in love with each other in the 80's, and they are met with nothing but acceptance. Towards the end of the film, During a terrifically written and emotional monologue, Elio's father offers his son love, acceptance and support. Call Me by Your Name is profoundly endearing, and a must-watch for all viewers. It's a depiction of the hardships and serene moments of a beautiful romance that makes it an instant classic.

Call Me By Your Name is a unique coming-of-age movie because it emphasizes the reality of young love stories. The cinematography beautifully sets a scene for a flawless love story, but Elio and Oliver's relationship is complex and takes a while to fully blossom. In the beginning of the film the couple wasted time that they could have spent together in other relationships because they were worried about what other people would think. Elio pursued a relationship with a girl almost to spite his feelings towards Oliver, trying to channel his sexual frustration elsewhere, and as soon as the couple got together he ended his previous entanglement. What makes this movie so special is the intense buildup to the passionate but short-lived romance, because they knew they didn't have much time together before Oliver inevitably returned home. When Elio arrives back from the train station in distress, his father comforts him and reassures him of one of life's most important lessons in his own words: ‘Tis better to have loved and lost than to never have loved at all. His father opens up about his own childhood and tells Elio that homosexuality was something that people wished away, and there was regret in his tone when he revealed that he was never able to experience a connection like Elio and Oliver had. Besides the ending by the fireplace that made it seem that Elio was upset, the conclusion of the movie had a nice message; some relationships can begin and end messily, but the important thing is that you grew from it.

Oh this movie... I have seen it at least 10 times and I think I am more emotional with each viewing.  It's truly a love story, plain and simple.  So beautiful and unapologetic. It was glorious to see this relationship develop and be welcomed, almost encouraged by those around them.  So refreshing and heartbreaking at the same time.  I will keep watching Elio and Oliver and cannot wait for their story to continue!

A stunning film both plot and scenery wise. I felt like I was being transported to somewhere in Northern Italy in 1984. What the film sometimes lacks in direct dialogue, it makes up for in beautiful shots and music. The music communicates the dynamic of Elio and Oliver in a very accurate way, repetitive sounds when they're tip-toeing around each other, and blatant love songs when they finally admit their feelings. The film also portrays the secrecy of being gay in the 80's. You can hear church bells frequently, as if mocking them. The film truly does a great job with non-diegetic sound, it's really what makes it aside from the chemistry between Elio and Oliver. The ending scene is particularly powerful, the off-screen sounds of life resuming while Elio cries over lost love. That is what makes this film a contemporary classic. Aside from the sounds and music, the relationships between the characters is what draws me into this film again and again. Timothee Chalamet and Armie Hammer create a sort of tension that you feel acutely aware of as an audience member, and I found myself on the edge of my seat just as much as Elio was waiting for answers. There's a certain charming awkwardness between them as they begin to develop their relationship. Throughout the film I could see the anxiety Elio constantly felt over Oliver and their avoidance of each other. Sometimes there isn't even dialogue in these moments, like when Elio can't find Oliver and we hear Sufjan Stevens' Futile Devices. Dialogue would make Elio's feelings more obvious, however Futile Devices does a great job all on its own, communicating the anxious feelings of waiting and uncertainty perfectly. The scene goes on for about two minutes, but I did not find myself bored, the song just fit too perfectly. A relationship where dialogue is very important however is the one between Elio and his father. The speech his dad gives Elio is beautiful and comforting. Call Me by Your Name is a must-see and an instant classic, in the LGBTQ+ community and beyond. It's a coming of age that is realistic and relatable, and takes the trope where it hasn't been explored before.
Man I've never had a movie hit me this hard before. This is a beautiful movie that might destroy you by the end.

Love the view, love the plot, and the characters...
Honestly I'm not sad ending person, but i really fall for this movie, i even still thinking about eliot and his feeling and how sad he is in front of the fireplace.

Like a big budget Lifetime Movie Network entertainment, with non of the redeeming camp values. I don't know what I found more insulting about this film: the lack of passionate connection between the two main characters, the director's aversion to directly showing gay sexual intimacy while presenting full frontal female nudity in heterosexual sex scenes, or the way this film treats the female characters like obtuse props. It has well shot beautiful settings, but I found myself thinking "all this pretty is so superficial." There was a suburban sensibility filter cast over everything. Even the infamous peach scene felt like a self conscious version of something that should have been a moment of erotic confrontation and intimacy between the two male leads. Armie Hammer may think he can pass for a 24 year old grad student, however reality has him reading at least 10 years too old for this part. Timothée Chalamet is actually quite good, but even his efforts, and the Italian setting can't bring any sensuality to this dry kiss of a film.

So, let's begin by saying that the film is really good, as a whole, no objections according to the plot, however, the film is highly overrated, yes, we have a great story whatsoever. Can we say it's a may-watch? Not really, it has a great plot, great cast, great atmosphere, yes, it has everything, but is not something from other world.

A stunning work of art, a cinematic masterpiece, and a contemporary LGBT classic. Timothée Chalamet and Armie Hammer create a tension, a chemistry and passion that go beyond the standard coming-of-age tale. Luca Guadagnino creates an intense setting with his choice of filming location, direction and artistic flair that is hard to come by in an independent film. Elio and Oliver's budding relationship can't be defined by one set label. Friends, lovers, roommates, a fling or a lifelong experience, the intense moments of pleasure and pain are perfectly captured in this gripping and sad film.

Call me by your name has excellent cinematography and strong performances and a lot of emotion. The movie is well done. That being said the movie is a A very big slow burn. At over two hours long I feel about 15 minutes could’ve been cut off the film and it does drag on in parts. Not sure if I’d say it’s one of the best movies of the year but it is very good especially for the cinematography and performances.

I can't think of a more beautiful love story. The dynamic between Chalamet and Hammer is incredible, there is true love between them. Chalamet gives his best performance yet in an young but inevitably legendary career. The last 20 minutes of this film leave the viewer's heart both shattered and fluttering with anticipation for the future of this series. I genuinely watch the credits to see Chalamet's final gift of acting. Finally Michael Stuhlbarg's monologue at the end will always bring me to tears, it is one of the most profound and beautiful monologues I've ever heard.

Beautifully filmed and acted love story set over the course of an Italian summer - but I found it much less subtle than I was expecting; I don't know what led me to expect a more nuanced film, but I found the symbolism and metaphors the film world with to be too on the nose, out of step with the power of the performances and the beautifully composed cinematography. And it left me more than a little concerned that the fact that Chalamet's character is below the legal age of consent (or did I get that wrong?) is barely raised as an issue throughout. A father-son scene towards the end, though, is beautifully judged and played, for me highlighting how much more I felt what went before could have been.
This film was so refreshing and a great take on a gay couple'a blossoming romance. The shots and acting were beautiful and I could I watch this film all day.

Difícil de explicar lo que es ésta película. La sensibilidad y madurez de Armie Hammer junto a la inexperiencia y ganas juveniles de explorar de Timothée Chalamet, junto al director Luca Guadagnino hacen una amalgama sensual y digna de la búsqueda del amor y la necesidad de sentirse necesitado e importante.
Todo sucede en un verano interminable en Italia. La interacción entre los personajes es digna y en ningún momento se le falta al respeto a nadie (incluso en escenas más que controvertidas).
La manera en la que el padre del personaje principal interpretado por Michael Stuhlbarg cobija y protege a su hijo del dolor de un rompimiento le dan una mención honorifica a su trabajo (ésa escena es de lo más hermoso que he visto en mi vida).
Ésta película es cómo una oruga que, lenta y bellamente vemos transformarse en una mariposa, que sin más; nos deja con una sensación de plenitud solamente por haber sido parte de ése proceso.
This movie made me feel alive in a way no other movie ever did. Warmth, love, passion, desire...this is a movie like no other.
Beautiful, engaging, and the biggest broken heart I ever seen. The aesthetic of this movie is just amazing

A unique gay romance film unlike any other. The acting and directing are tremendously extraordinary, it feels like you can even understand without any dialogue. The filming and soundtrack are melancholic, dreamy, and breathtaking. The two main actors really conveyed the true sentiments of the lover's mesmerizing love with each other. The movie features a roller coaster of emotions in each scene which makes it a one of a kind movie.
great performances by the actors.
This movie stayed with me long afterwards; the cinematography, the acting, the story the everything was captivating.
Absolutely fantastic.

This is my favorite movie of all time. The vibes are immaculate, the casting is amazing, the story is incredible, the cinematography and locations are also just breathtaking. I can't put in words how good this movie is! Timothée Chalamet and Armie Hammer do such a wonderful job in this movie.

This movie is real life on screen. It grabs hold of every sense of your being and doesn't let go until the end, I was changed forever after this movie. I know for myself being a woman and gay this story related and to my friends straight as well because the love between these two beautifully portrayed characters, it really only shows love not gender. The performances by Armie Hammer(Oliver) and Timothée Chamalet(Elio) are captivating and give new life into portraying love and Michael Stuhlbarg's(Mr. Perlman) portrayal captures a supportive parent and the monologue at the end of the movie is one that has stuck with me and I remind myself about constantly, as well as changed the way I will parent my kids. This movie is a coming-of-age film where the slow burn of desire and passion for another person in the reality of life is portrayed in the most simplest and accurate forms. Loved the movie and would recommend anyone to see it.

There was no emotional connection between these two characters. Their laying around and huffing and puffing by the pool made them seemed like they were bored and had nothing better to than each other. Overrated.

'Vision of Gideon' rendered me into emptiness and looking into Timothee's eyes left me incapable of controlling my deep dark agonizing pain.

I thought I’d love this movie based off the reviews and plot description. Though the acting was superb and it was an intriguing story, I was extremely bored throughout the majority of the film and was ready for it to be over long before it was.

Whilst the film contained hidden truths that were beautifully excavated by the conclusion of the film about first love and grief, it was undermined by a significant amount of eroticism that seemingly comes out of nowhere. There was no emotional foundation to the relationship – it happens quickly – and whilst the landscape and cinematography is beautiful, the pervading discomfort was the elephant in the room – and undermined the beauty this film had to offer.
The directing, the beautiful Italian scenery, and the complex characters are what make Luca Guadagnino's Call Me By Your Name a cinematic sensation!

Call Me By Your Name is an indie type of film that is directed by Luca Guadagnino that stars Timothée Chalamet, who plays a teenage boy, named Elio who explores his sexuality, and meets and falls in love with an older gentleman named Oliver, who is played Armie Hammer, during one summer in the 1980's. Oliver and Elio's relationship is kickstarter with the Oliver living in his family's house for the summer while helping Elio's father with some archaeological assignments in the area.
There were many interesting aspects about the film, however a very intriguing part of the film lies with Elio's character development and arc. At the start of the film, Timothée had not had a sexual partner previous to this summer in France. As the film progresses, Elio initially becomes more deeply involved with his girlfriend at the time, but eventually gets torn between she and his feelings and desires for Oliver. Eventually Elio falls for Oliver and things are good for a short period of time between them. Oliver goes back to America and Elio finds out that Oliver is getting married, then completing Elio's character arc. The character arc of Elio provides evidence of an underlying social commentary. The film shows a very detailed social commentary on the fluidity of sexuality, relationships, and love. Both Elio and Oliver love each other, but that does not mean that they cannot love others, or other types of people. Call Me By Your Name shows there is no limitation to what one can or cannot love or be sexually attracted to. 
Though there were many positives to this film, I can't help but feel that Elio's emotional roller coaster throughout the film was not supported by the film's pacing, which made it extremely difficult to stay engaged. Overall I give Call Me By Your Name a 7/10.

As the love between these two characters unfold they are free to be who they want to be and to love who they want to love. There is no judgement, no shame, no humiliation. They just simply are, to men who are wholeheartedly in love. 
We see the undying flames lit between Elio and Oliver. And it's sadly something that we don't get to see a lot of.
