The film, Call Me By Your Name (2017), directed by Luca Guadagnino, showcases love through the atmospheric encapsulation of nostalgia, seduction, and intimacy. Throughout the narrative, powerful storytelling comes from impeccable cinematography and profound sound design. The minimized details of movement and ambiance guide a ‘will they- won't they' dynamic between the two lovers through the progression of the plot. The movie successfully paints a queer relationship through a tension that is embedded in its direction, and it does so in a way that can pull on audiences' heart strings and relate to a global audience on an authentic level.  
To allude to the attraction between the main characters Elio and Oliver, Call Me By Your Name uses various methods of diegetic sound. It's important to recognize the beauty of diegetic sound because not only are these the noises sourced within the story world, but they become clues to the exchange of secrecy and freedom. The chemistry between the two characters builds from slight interactions to intellectual conversation, growing closer with each movement- each step. For instance, the sound of a footstep can be detailed in scenes when they are walking around the town, even if the camera suggests a wider shot to capture the environment. Off-screen sound occurs from a source that is assumed to be in the space, but is outside of what is visible on screen. A majority of the sound in this film can be described as romantically ambient through off-screen sound. Outdoor noises flood the audience's ears to suggest nature as a shield to the outside world but also as a playground to fall in love with someone. It sounds as if the volume of dialogue is raised to compensate for the engines of passing vehicles, the chirps of of morning birds, and the constant movement or roar of water. 
Similarly, the cinematography displays the beauty of the landscape, encapsulating warm, vibrant colors during the day and maintains similar granular textures through the use of a film camera. The consistency of these visual summertime cues establish how present the characters were with each other.  The composition of these shots are remarkably creative. There is a scene in which Elio confesses his emotions towards Oliver and the camera points to the ringing of church bells to show a presence of guilt and religion. It shows a story. It doesn't just tell it. The cinematography is smart, and therefore, watching this movie is deeply entertaining. 
Call Me By Your Name exemplified romance and seduction with nature playing a supporting role to emphasize how Elio and Oliver chose to exist within it. In our modern society, the film started a conversation about the LGBTQA+ community in a manner that pushes beyond the barrier of queer fetishization through the depiction of  genuine adoration of another person's soul and dealing with the consequences of its inevitable ending. It explores how love can be even more limiting past the limitation of fate and timing because it extends to societal pressure, reputation, and linked misery. This movie was gorgeously rendered and boundary-breaking, and for that reason, I would give this film a 4.5/5 star rating.

"Call Me By Your Name" tells the story of a complex, passionate, developing first love between a 17-year-old named Elio (Timothee Chalamet) and an American student named Oliver (Armie Hammer). The complexity of this relationship stems from multiple things; one of which being that they're both males, and they question whether or not them being together is "right." Elio's father-an archaeology professor- hosts an American student to work along side him every summer at their home in northern Italy, which is how the two are introduced to begin with. 

Something close to the epitome of cinematography, this movie is beautifully shot across multiple locations in Italy. With the color palette and costuming of the characters seamlessly working together to give a nature-like feel, any one scene from this film is just as visually captivating as the next. The director requested to the cinematographer- Sayombhu Mukdeeprom- to shoot the entire movie using one 35mm lens. Successfully completing this request, Mukdeeprom created an objective, natural, more authentic perspective for the viewers to watch from. He perfectly captured the raw, vulnerable emotion exuded from both Elio and Oliver as the plot unfolds, of which the people watching could connect, empathize with, and relate to with ease. 

Furthermore, though some say the movie is slow to pick up, I feel that the slower progression of both Oliver and Elio really internalizing their feelings was needed for the development of their relationship. The director-Luca Guadagnino- brilliantly giving them the time to grow at a slower pace allowed what they had on-screen to be portrayed as something of a deeper, more sensual meaning to the viewer. Elio's parents quickly catch on to how things are between him and Oliver, which is shown by the two giving subtle hints to both boys throughout the film. 

Finally, this immensely relatable, entrancing, emotionally provoking coming-of-age film shows the reality of two humans being attracted to one another for the personalities they embody, regardless of gender. This is significant and extremely eye-opening to the people watching, being that this is not an usual thing shown in films that are done as well as this film was. "Call Me By Your Name" is an intense, powerful masterpiece that is undoubtedly worth the watch.

Call Me By Your Name beautifully portrays the fear and joy that comes falling in love. The chemistry between Timothee Chalemet's Elio and Armie Hammers Oliver is undeniable as they find each other whilst riding bikes through scenic northern Italy. Chalemet captures audiences with his raw, organic performance of how it feels to fall in love with the added uncertainty of coming to terms with Elios sexuality. 
Oliver, a graduate student studying abroad alongside Elio's father comes off as a handsome American playboy who all the young women seem to swoon over. His cocky slang and arrogant attitude at the start of the film create an uneasiness that is not subdued till later once hi feelings toward Elio are revealed. His more masculine energy disrupts the more feminine, ethereal, lifestyle that he learns to adapt to. 
Contrarily Elio, much more introverted finds himself longing to leave his family's Italian hideaway as prior to Oliver's arrival we can assume he spends his days reading alone or writing music and playing the piano. We follow Elio as he falls for Oliver, we watch his longing when Oliver is not around and his fer of saying the wrong thing around him. We watch the pairs' anxieties as the both develop their feelings and how the fear of them falling is coupled with the homophobic stigma at that time and the end of summer approaching.
Visually the film will stun audiences with cobblestone streets and organic Italian architecture. Earthy tones are present throughout the film connecting the audience with the warm summer outdoor lifestyle when Oliver and elios story takes place. The film very much resembles a paradise of sorts with both Oliver and Elio being away from home, Oliver more than elio, the couple engages in this sort of freedom to live and fall in love. 
CallMeByYour Name is tender and fresh. It is a love story that is felt by many yet rarely told. Viewers fall in love with the protagonists' idealism and longing for one another but are inevitably heartbroken and left to just remember the warmth that first loves bring.

Call Me By Your Name was an incredible movie. From the visuals to the music, and the realistic atmosphere it gave off. Call Me By Your Name may not be like most romantic and or love movies but it's one of my favorite. It may start off slow but it does gradually build and begins to speed up.  It's not your typical film where it's obvious what's going to happen, "oh yea of course they're going to fall in love." The movie is filled with great suspense and keeps you wanting to see more and indulge in it more. From the relationship seen with Elios family and friends to his relationship with Oliver, love is very important. Knowledge is important. Call Me By Your Name has many great characteristics as a film. It covers many aspects as to personal, religious, family, cultural and many more. I truly enjoyed this film because it felt way more than just that. It felt real, captivating almost. When I say captivating I'm talking about the natural flow between Elio and Oliver. They completely tuned into their characters very well. The directors eye for this was perfect. I honestly don't think the film could get any better, If I could I would add more! Some movies catch the eye but some really speak to the soul. This move may not go that deep but you will have a smile on your face more than once throughout the duration of the film. All in all, yes watch this movie, you won't regret it!

Call me by your name invites the viewer to explore the relationships held between Elio and those in his environment, to those held by the viewer themselves. More specifically, the relationships between Elio and Oliver, Elio and his father, and Elio and his self. 

First, I will explore the blossoming relationship between Elio (Timothée Chalamet) and Oliver (Armie Hammer). As Elio is living with Oliver, his attraction and curiosity grow exponentially with each intimate interaction. This is, as we learn, is shared by the likes of Oliver. Although Oliver's attraction toward Elio began around the same time, his approaches are calculated and reserved. This could be attributed to the age difference or the fact that he is working closely for Elio's father and has been invited to stay within their home. Eventually, Oliver replicates his feelings towards Elio. Promoted only after Elio expresses his feelings to Oliver, with "these things." Their relationship allows the viewer to recap likewise awakening moments and intimacies throughout their lives. 

Second, the open relationship between Elio and his father. Many can say Elio is lucky to have a father that is as open and accepting as that of Elio's. Without reservation, his father accepts Elio and his coming of age. One instance, when Elio openly admits that he almost had sex with a local, Marcie. This honesty and transparency are not often shared between father and son. This concept is further explored when Elio's father shares a relationship similar to that of Elio and Oliver. He invited Elio to hold onto that moment, and is even jealous - due to the fact that he had a similar opportunity and was not courageous enough to pursue himself. The relationship allows the viewer to either relate to that of their fathers, or wish to have had a relationship so open and honest. 

Lastly, the relationship between Elio and himself. Elio throughout the course of the movie is searching for different things. That of self actualization, self acceptance, sexuality enlightenment, and every thing an adolescent faces. This ebbs and flows as he kisses Oliver, groping him - then weeks later presumably loses his virginity to Marcie. It is only after Oliver leaves that reality sets in for Elio - and his resolved relationship ending brings only more questions of sexuality and how he will continue in his life. The viewer is able to assess their own life - thinking of their growth, experiences held, self actualization, and ultimate worldview. Additionally, we all can relate to Elio staring into the fire as the movie rolls credits - as he fully realizes there would be no longer a possibility for Elio to continue with Oliver.

Call Me By Your Name is a must see movie. It starts off a little slow in the beginning but then it quickly starts to bloom into something so amazing. You'll never go into a scene without hearing the sounds of bells as if someone was getting married. It has this calming yet mysterious setting to it. One moment everything is at ease and then the next it's all over the place but in a good way. The way the movie started if seemed like it was going to be just an ordinary cliché chick flick. But it wasn't it was something more. The movie truly began to bloom when Elio and Oliver started this on and off type of love or fling. Their love for each other was spontaneous and admiring. It was the type of love you could not control your actions or what your heart desired. Now it was sexual, but it didn't make me feel uncomfortable. You understood why it had to be apart of the movie. What made the movie quite difficult to understand was Elio's relationship with a girl named Marzia. They had a little something going on as well. But when Elio and Oliver started their love quest it made me question why still talk to Marzia in that way. The music in this movie particularly had a major role as it carried one seen to the next scene. The end was probably my favorite scene in the whole movie. Just the way it tied everything together and the song that played. It was a heartbreaking scene but it was a peaceful once as well. I highly recommend this movie to anyone and everyone.

The film, Call Me by Your Name is one of the most romantic coming to age films ever produced. It's one of my favorites of all time. The director, Luca Guadagnino uses a vast amount of cinematography elements to allow us, the audience to be a part of Elio's and Oliver's relationship and the film itself. These elements presented in the film creates a more Realism approach like you are there in the movie even though it set in the 1980's. 

The very last scene of the film, where Elio is crying and holding himself white sitting in front of the fire in his house. During this last scene, the title of the movie appears on the screen. The camera doesn't change screens, but stays constant on Elio even when the credits roll on. The nondigetic sound of the fire represents more than just fire it indicates the relationship Elio once had with Oliver. It's burning and fading, he looks at the fire like he's looking back in the past when it was summer and the times he had with Oliver. This emotional and intimate scene, Elio is holding himself because he knows he is going to be okay and he'll grow from this. 
It has Elio looking back at his first true love, which provided him a better understanding of himself thus he grew. Many of us don't have to be homosexuals to relate to the film. The film is shot by one perspective, one tone and one way. This camera work allows us to be intimate with the characters in the film. We all experience a first something and grew from it, it might hurt us at that time, but we all have to face our feelings and go through pain in order to move on and grow from it.

"Call Me By You Name" is a powerful film that follows a 17 year old boy and his first love. It captures the ardent emotions that rapidly developed and blossomed Though the film is not fast paced drama or even heavy in dialogue , it still full of intensity and rich in emotion. The journey from the start is a slow but very much needed and well executed build. You don't even realize you are in the thick of it until after the fact. But once you realize that they have finally expressed their feelings toward one another, the film still manages to build from there. These emotions are conveyed not only by the incredible performance of the actors but also the quality of scenes and the diegetic sounds. Every single sound within the world of this film adds to the meaning of this time constrained love story, whether it be the loud screeching of a bus or the ring of church bells. In each scene you can hear the most seemingly unimportant sounds, like birds chirping and water crashing onto rocks from the top of waterfalls. The fact that the viewers and audience can each and every sound makes your body become aware of everything that is being carried out in the scene. These natural and intense sounds mirror the feelings and passion that Elio (Timothee Chalamet) and Oliver (Armie Hammer) have developed and shard for each other. This film explores love and its limits in a sensitive and sensual way. It takes the viewers from the beginning to end, because this love story does end only a few days after it started.

'Call Me By Your Name' is a quick, luscious, and slowly seductive escapade that envelopes the viewer into the summer love story of Elio and Oliver. This movie is a rapture, an absolute necessity - as it pulls the viewer through the most profound moments of young love. However, this is not a boy gets a girl coming of age - this is the delicate dance between queer men as they tease out their intentions. 

The story unfolds in a lively private space. Rapid and successive tight shots lead us into the private details of Elio's home in northern Italy. These moments pass by, allowing us almost to taste the cracked egg, feel the breeze, speak the romantic languages of French, Italian, and Latin. 

The lighting is natural - the tone warm - evocative of sensual human pleasures as well as the safety of home and family. Oliver becomes a disruption to this - his skin glistening more than the river - his language curt. Elio teases Oliver's American mannerisms at dinner, "just watch this is how he will say goodbye to us when the time comes: Later." 

These visual moments often cut between dual tensions: water and earth; freedom and time. These choices are deliberate. In the scene where Elio is playing the piano to his father's guests on the night, he and Oliver are meant to meet at midnight. The camera pans from vicarious music playing to wristwatch-subverting to the audience the ending we know will happen, but hope will never come. 

Although we see each of these tight shots of the summer and Elio and Oliver, we feel the altered sound perspective, making the domestic elements a sort of 'main character.' We see the floorboards, but we hear them creak as if they are speaking to us; remember this is a secret - this is love - this is taboo.  

This 'main character' - the sounds of the house - pull us in closer and closer as the story unravels, each moment becomes a tease - a playful analogy to what could be for Elio and Oliver. Eventually, we even hear the slightest touch until Elio and Oliver are finally overwhelmed by each other. 

In the end, however, Oliver, who was only there for six weeks, leaves to go back home. However, this is only one heartbreak Elio experiences. The last part of the story cuts forward, and once again, the play of tensions is at work. Although here, it is the tension between snow and fire.  

Oliver calls to inform the family he is getting married. When Elio hangs up the phone, he goes to sit by the fireplace, cracking and bright. Behind him, we can see a window. The snow falls outside - dense and quiet. We are with Elio in his last heartbreak. The house has him caught between his past. The dynamic and passionate love of Oliver reflected in the fire's glow on Elio's face, and his future, we see out the window behind him silent healing.

Call me by your name COULD feel as long as trying to say the title, "The Assassination of Jesse James By The Coward Robert Ford." Although this may be deemed as bad, I personal think its a double sided sword. On one side, if you appreciate the love, heavy sound illustration and extreme amount of detail within the dialog, the time is gracefully distributed. However, if you miss the "love train," the run-time may feel like an endless loop of pretty shots. I will say I am on the good side of this sword for the most part. I can't help it, I LOVE love. The love story that's told is such a unique story within the complications of a gay relationship that I can only appreciate what is being told. Love is a universal topic and I think it's translated here perfectly. As a straight man I still felt all the compassion and emotion between Elio and Oliver, our lovers. Our lovers start off with very innocent and brief interactions which was so easy to get attached too. (Now back to my double sided sword analogy) If you're on the bad side of things you may feel like this movie is a drag and a waste of time. I get it, this movie is LOOOOONG and the shots take a lot of patience to sit through. It's like raising a child I'd imagine. From a young age you sit and wait for your kid to adapt to a very beautiful flower. Luckily the child this film adapted into was a very elegant and well thought out composition with sound bridges so well placed you forget how important your ears actually are. This movie will stand against time as far as love goes, blending in with this new age of compassion and love.

Call Me By Your Name struck me as a piece of art as well as a cinematic success. While it did have its shortcomings, I found it entertaining and moving overall. The location, "north italy," along with the cinematography created this mystical world for the story to unfold within. The story balances melancholy and beautiful moments well as Elio continuously struggles with his identity, juxtaposed with him falling in love with Oliver and accepting what is being built between the two of them. I believe the only quarrels I have with the film are it's pacing and the lack of societal struggle and outside influence that Elio is faced with. The pacing, while intentionally slow in the beginning, seems almost too slow in the first half of the film. It certainly creates a build up for the beautiful explosion of their love for eachother, yet it felt too sluggish for me personally. Though in perspective, I typically appreciate action and fast paced films, so this take on the pacing is highly biased and I recognize that to some it may not seem that way to some. My second and only other problem with the movie is the lack of struggle presented to Elio considering the time period. It all seems too perfect that he is so accepted and loved by his parents and those around him regardless of the societal climate in 1983 surrounding the LGBTQ community. With those complaints, it still didn't take away from the overall experience and message the film conveyed. It shone through those imperfections with excellent cinematography, acting, and storyline. Scene to scene everything down to the ambient sound is done with nothing but pure intention alluding the audience to what is occuring emotionally within Elio or Oliver. Every single character is casted to their part suitably and acts it out in a way that is immersive, especially Timothee Chalamet. All in all, Call Me By Your Name is a magical coming-of age tale, and was very moving to me. I would give this film a 4.5/5

The film Call Me By Your Name takes place in the summer of 1983 in northern Italy. The main characters, Oliver and Elio, accurately portray what it's like to struggle with sexuality when religion and conservative ideals stand in your way. Timothee Chalamet, who plays the part of Elio, does a stellar job at portraying the innocent nature of a 17-year-old who is struggling to discover himself as he ventures into a secret relationship with an older man, Oliver, who is working for his father. While the film accurately captured the intimate journey of two men who are just discovering their sexualities, the plot itself seems too good to be true. During this time period, being gay was something that wasn't close to being fully accepted yet. The fact that Oliver an Elio faced little to no retributions or hatred for their relationship was unusual to me, being that they also lived in an area where religion was a part of everyones' family life. While the film's intent was to portray this intimate relationship in a beautiful way, it was not as realistic as one would expect. While viewers enjoy seeing a romanticized love story with little to no struggles, it sends the wrong message to viewers who are struggling with their sexualities. For instance, in the scene where Elio's father talks to him about his relationship with Oliver, he is fully supportive and even makes a reference to himself struggling with his own sexuality but being too afraid to act on it. So not only does Elio's very religious father accept him being gay with no question, but he also reveals that he has experienced feelings of the same nature. So while Call Me By Your Name was beautifully filmed and has a plot that moves people of all ages and sexualities, it was too unrealistic for its setting.

I struggle to rate this movie because I simultaneously love it and hate it. The cinematography of the film is beautiful. The framing and color keep the film interesting visually during slower scenes. The sounds of 1980's Italy: birds chirping, bicycles, creaky hardwood floors of Elio's family's estate, and the sounds of the countryside set an overall nostalgic and comforting mood for the film without becoming boring and while still creating meaning. Outside of the non-diegetic sound, the soundtrack paired is  one of my personal favorites of any film. The mood of the film follows the songs chosen and produced to a tee: hopeful during Elio and Oliver's last adventures together and bittersweet and reminiscent when Elio receives a phone call from Oliver later telling him he's getting married. Repeated loops of sound created a repeated feeling of sweetness that made my heart melt for the two. The editing uses sound in ways to invoke feeling in its watchers in a way I doubt I've ever seen in any other films. That being said, I also hold a grudge against the film within my own personal taste. I strongly believe that there needs to be more representation surrounding LGBT+ coming of age stories and/or romances. However, I also believe that not all representation is good representation. Throughout the entirety of the movie I couldn't get over the large age gap between Elio and Oliver, which was often played up through camera angles and framing. It felt predatory at times, for example when Elio watches Oliver leave, the camera framing and angle works to make him Elio appear child-like. In addition to that, the constant and detailed sex scenes over-fetishized the relationship in my opinion, one example being the famous and slightly disturbing scene involving a peach which uses detailed sound to make the scene even more pornographic. I would have loved to see a more relatable  love story between to two, maybe a sex scene here or there and without the age gap. I feel as though this would have helped to create a more positive portrayal of the gay relationship and could have created a positive form of representation, rather than adding to the harmful  and untrue stigma surrounding gay relationships as being more hyper-sexual or predatory than straight ones. The film did have some moments of sweetness and a positive relationship between the two, but overall it felt very far from most types of relationships portrayed between straight couples in other films. I praise the film for its use of sound and cinematography in itself, it's a beautiful experience to listen to and watch. However, the plot and characters and even sound and cinematography at times, did very little to work forward for gay representation in film and in some ways I fear may have even added to existing stigmas in some viewers' eyes. I appreciate the film for its artistry but would recommend looking elsewhere if looking for an LGBT+ film with a positive message.

"Call Me By Your Name" is a striking coming-of-age story, following 17 year-old Elio and 24 year-old Oliver in their queer discovery. I personally thought that the director, Luca Guadagnino, did a wonderful job with incorporating precise and intentional camerawork into the story. In one scene Oliver and Elio ride their bikes out to a monument and begin discussing their feelings. At one moment the camera pans upward to show a church, then shifts downward again to reveal Elio standing alone just peering up at it. This shot is almost a bit eerie feeling because of the way it is presented to the viewer. The church is there to represent Elio coming to terms with his sexuality in the face of religion, no doubt a daunting task. Since both Elio and Oliver are Jewish, this camerawork only deepens that frightening feeling they must be going through, fearing rejection from something they have grown so close to. Besides knowing how to make proper use of a camera, Guadagnino is skillful in how sound is presented to the viewer. It makes us aware of Elio's internal struggles with his sexuality. Diegetic sound is utilized in scenes where Elio is playing the piano, basically pouring out his feelings for Oliver in the best way he knows how. In contrast, nondiegetic sound can be found in the film through the transitions between scenes where there is a small piano motif. I found that in many of the scenes where this musical phrase plays, Elio is thinking about his feelings for Oliver. It is a small signal to us while watching that Elio is truly overcome by struggle with his sexuality throughout the whole of the film, since these nondiegetic sounds occur up until the very end. Speaking of the end, there isn't a more powerful shot than Elio gazing into the fire after learning that Oliver is engaged to a woman. An incredible performance by Timothee Chalamet, the viewer can see his tortured thoughts simply through his glazed over eyes and the shadows cast around him from the fire. I can now say that "Call Me By Your Name" is one of my new go-to movies, for when I need to cry, laugh, or contemplate deeply about my own life.

If I had a dollar for every time I found myself lost in the cinematography of this film, I would be able to produce every movie featuring these two amazing actors. The film touches on the topic of queerness and coming to terms with your true identity and how it affects the close people around you. Elio (Timothee Chamalet) is a 17 year old living in Italy in the year of 1987. His father (Michael Stuhlbarg) is a very decorated professor who focused mainly on Architecture. In this particular summer, Oliver (Armie Hammer) visits their home in Italy to work as an intern for Elio's father. During this time they are together, you can watch as the bond between Elio and Oliver grows. Getting to the point of having a romantic relationship near the end of the summer.

I was blown away by the way the film was able to teach things to the audience. Visually the film is breathtaking. Being in the beautiful city of Italy alone already gives it a plus but the cinematography was easily admirable. One scene in particular that really caught my attention was the famous statue scene. This scene can be argued as the climax of the film due to Elio confessing his true feelings to Oliver. The way this scene was shot was with using a technique called a Long Take, meaning there were no cuts. Being an actor, I know how it can sometimes be risky to have people act for a long period of time without being able to take a break. Luckily, Luca Guadagnino, the director of the film, took this risk and I feel everyone who saw it can admire his decision to do so. 

I loved every second of this film. Somewhat of an embarrassment to admit, I have a very small attention span. It takes a lot for me to actually sit through a film and enjoy it. Call Me By Your Name uses a concept knows as a "Forward." This means that the actions of the characters either verbally or physically causes the audience to want to know what happens next. Due to the film keeping this up all the way to the beautiful end credit scene, led to me on the edge of my seat wanting to know the next action. This is a definite shout-out to the writer of this film because he deserves a lot of credit for it's success. I highly recommend this film to anyone who simply just likes movies for the story, cinematography, and the writing. 

Loved it!

Dawson Garrett

"Call Me by Your Name" is a beautifully shot movie and you can tell that it is well thought out. The scenes flow together beautifully  and the movie as a whole gives off a sense or nostalgia. The movie does a lot with sound that is clever, but may be too loud for some. The use of sound bridges really tied a lot of scenes together that without them could have been bland. However, the dialogue in the movie is cheesy and unecessary and it can't be ignored that Oliver is a predator. Throughout most of the film Elio continues to have childish outbursts which seems to only make Oliver more attracted to him. Each caress, kiss, and embrace they share is only clouded in the fact that Elio and Oliver being together is 100% wrong. Although their relationship seems romantic, when the parents are around you are once again reminded that Elio is a child and that this relationship should jot be allowed to happen. Not only this, but the dialogue leaves much to be imagined. Long monologues are given where they aren't needed and it seems that people are just stringing word together to make whatever they say sound poetic instead of it actually making sense. There are many scenes that are so uncomfortable in the movie that they are hard to watch(i.e.the peach scene.) It seems as if the movie drags on which make sit feel like three days rather than two hours. All in all "Call Me by Your Name" Is a beautifully shot film with lots of great aspects of cinematography, but everything else falls short and make the film boring.

"Call Me By Your Name" is an incredible film that was put together by an amazing director, Luca Guadagnino. Tremendous actors in this film included Timothee Chalamet and Armie Hammer. The film starts off in Northern Italy in 1983, when Timothee Chalamet (Elio) meets Armie Hammer (Oliver). Elio is a 17 year old boy and Oliver is a doctoral student who works for Elio's father as an intern over the summer. It's an overwhelming, exciting love story between the two. However, it slowly unravels due to Oliver's departure to the United States. Throughout the time Oliver stayed in the same house as Elio, he began to find his true self. Elio kept the relationship with Oliver a secret due to his religion. He also kept it secret because he also had a girlfriend at the time and was afraid of what his parents might say. Elio's parents didn't suspect a thing between the two, they just thought they were becoming best friends. As it came time for their relationship to come to an end, Elio's parents thought it was a good idea for the two to go on a mini vacation together. On the vacation together they became more intimate with one another, but on the last night upon being with each other everything became unsettling. In the scene where Oliver was looking out the window and turned around to look at Elio while he was sleeping. Elio had a sonic flashback of all the memories he had with Oliver. Once Elio put Oliver onto the train and it began to depart, he began to feel an unbearable pain in his heart. He felt as if he'd never feel that connection with anyone ever again.

Call Me by Your Name is a gripping film in which a teenage boy is discovering his sexuality. It's spinning with hidden meaning and deep feelings that the characters try to keep concealed from one another. The accuracy in which the film manages to capture Elio's expression of his emotions portrayed wonderfully by Timothy Chalet and it captures the feeling of fumbling in the dark and trying to find yourself in your teenage years. It's visually transfixing with the Italian scenery as well as the sound and music that plays a key role within the film. The music in Elio's scenes are important representative auditory factors in his self-discovery throughout the film. Also, the background noise plays a key role in certain intimate scenes. Costuming and makeup are done to perfection with the time period from the outfits to the hair. The film calls to a younger adult audience can that can find easy relation in this film due to the coming of age vibe that pertains to it. The film does contain one definitive flaw. Oliver (played by Armie Hammer) is the college-aged man who catches Elio's interest. This presents a moral issue in the sense that Elio is 17 years old and Oliver is 24 years old, yet Oliver engages in a sexual and emotional relationship with him. I found Oliver's character was overly romanticized considering that he and Elio's relationship would be very taboo and very illegal in most places. If you put it in the standard of a straight relationship, it'd have been put to an end immediately. What is odd is that Elio's parents seem to know about him and Oliver though it's unspoken. They have no problem with this completely age-inappropriate relationship.

The love story that come about from in "Call Me by Your Name "is one that you would think could happen in a movie.  During the time era that this movie took place their love towards one another would have been frowned upon by people around them. They had an instant attraction that could be seen and felt from the very beginning of the movie making it more intense. 
While watching this movie I found myself personally getting sucked in and getting lost. I felt like I was part of the film, the sound effects were so realistic, and the graphics and scenes just made everything go together. The music that is played is all played by piano and seems to make us feel that scene more intense. Leo's and Elio relationship are also one that you just sit there and just want to push and make it work for them.
"Call Me by Your Name "is a beautiful love story that opens your eyes that you can find love in any place. It also lets you know just as fast as you can fall in love you heart can be broken just as fast. Don't let love pass you by, if you love someone let them know before it's too late.

This has to be in my top 5 favorite films ever! I loved everything Luca Guadagnino did from direction, to choosing the actors, and  the particular Classical pieces. I also loved how he specifically shot little details that people do not normally see and hear while watching a movie. This film is a work of art and very passionate; it shows the friendship blossoming into love between Elio and Oliver in the summer of 1983 in a little town in northern Italy. When watching this film I noticed that it has a lot of repetition from the sounds, to the music, and dialogue. With dialogue, Oliver tends to say "Later" throughout the film. With sound and music, Elio plays classical pieces on the piano that show up throughout the movie conveying its importance to the audience that it is going to be a recurring theme/song that represents Elio and Oliver's blooming relationship. I loved watching this film because of the connection these two characters (Elio and Oliver) have with each other and how hesitant they are at first and how scary it can be to have those type of feelings, especially in that time period. Also with Elio's parents and how they view Elio and Oliver's relationship and their love for Elio and how they just want him to live life and embrace everything around at 17 years old. I also loved seeing the struggles they face within themselves and to express their feelings and emotions. The film takes you through different emotions from the beginning to the heartbreaking end. It goes deeper than sexuality; It sheds light on family, religion, emotions, dreams, and growing up.

This is one of the best sounding films I've personally ever seen to date. Luca Guadagnino did an amazing job of making sure you could hear every little detail in the film. From birds chirping to church bells ringing it was all there and important information to take in as you watched. This film was perfectly shot in the city of Paris in the summer of 1983. Taken place in the household of Elio(an American teen living in itlay)and his family, an exchange student by the name of Oliver came to stay with them because Elios dad is an archeologists professor. Over the summer the two grow to connect and build a strong relationship. What really stands out is the different types of sounds you hear, depending on the situation and mood of the characters. The way Elio was playing the song on the piano was good, but not the way it should be played. Oliver kept telling him to be yourself and play the original version. In the moment it didn't seem like a big deal but when you actually look back on it later Oliver was meaning a whole lot more then just the song. Another beautiful sound element in the movie was when they were standing by the waterfall and it felt like you were there with them about to get blown away. The more you watch this movie the more you fall in love with the sounds Luca chose to put in the movie. This is an amazing film about two teenagers that exchange a strong relationship over a summer and there struggles that come with.

This movie captivates anyone who watches it and the acute observations of desire and the story shot from Elio's point of view is agonizingly heartbreaking but beautiful in a very breathtaking manner. The scene where Elio is telling Oliver the history of the statue in town and Oliver asks him why Elio is telling him this, Elio responds saying 'because I though you should know'. When Oliver repeats Elio's answer with a questionable tone, Elio walks around the statue quietly repeating 'because I thought you should know', to then whispering 'because I wanted you to know', with a tone that sounded less doubtful and its Elio's way of confirming to himself that he feels something for Oliver. The dialogue between Oliver and Elio shows that Oliver wanted Elio to be more confident in himself and what he actually wants and the usage of repetition in the scene shows Elio is questioning himself as to why he would open up to Oliver and tell him the history of the statue. After Elio repeats that quote to himself a couple of times, he comes to the realization that he wanted Oliver to know that story of the statue and his sense of doubt is gone. 
   Another thing that I had noticed in this movie was how the two characters never actually said 'I love you' to one another. However, viewers are able to the characters have strong feelings for each other by their facial expressions. In the scene where Oliver is about to leave and Elio goes with him to see him off, they both embrace each other in silence and the viewers can tell that these two characters obviously felt more than just lust for one another, they had a true connection. When Oliver goes on the train and as it begins to move, there is an extreme long shot view of the train and Elio looking at the train as it gets further ad further away. The use of cinematography in that scene was able to show me how much Elio was going to miss Oliver because even though the train was starting to leave the shot, Elio remained at the train tracks and kept looking in the direction of the train. And the finale scene of the movie, when Elio and Oliver had their last conversation with each on the phone, and Elio repeats his name to Oliver on the phone, I think that this use of repetition in this dialogue is Elio's way of saying 'i love you' to Oliver. Through out the movie Elio is unsure and nervous while with Oliver, however, towards the end of this film, it is Oliver who is now unsure and nervous with Elio in their last phone conversation, their roles have become reversed towards the end of the movie.

Call Me by Your name is a seemingly perfect coming of age story. This film displays all of the feelings that a teenager feels while helplessly lusting after another. Call Me by Your Name is set during the summertime when everything is brighter. I think this is a highly important factor to the film. I'm sure viewers, like my own self, can reminisce back to a time during summer where all felt hopeful. This is precisely the summer that Elio was experiencing.  While I adored the indie vibe that this film presented all throughout the film, there was one specific moment that even months after watching has stuck with me. The end of Call Me by Your Name could not have ended any better. Timothee Chalamet perfectly displays heart break at the end of the film after his characters receives a phone call with the news that his summertime lover is planning to get married to someone besides himself. This film uses non-diegetic sound as the song Visions of Gideon by Sufjan Stevens plays. The lyrics seem to be written on Timothees face. This film displays true emotion as he looks off into the distance with clear heartbreak written on his face. With its repetitive lyrics, it is clear to the viewers that Timothees character is reminiscing on all of his memories with his summertime lover as the lyrics, "is it a video" play. While this film could've ended on a happier note, I personally don't think it should have. The end displays a very real reality that many people struggling with their sexuality face. This makes the movie even more relatable to viewers that face this struggle. Call Me by Your Name will definitely have you itching to view it again, and for that, I say kudos to the director, Luca Guadagnino.

In Luca Guadagnino's inspiring, compelling and even suspenseful drama/romance film , "Call Me By Your Name", a young boy 17-year old boy in Italy named Elio is faced with conflicting feelings of being queer when faced with his father's summer intern/doctoral student, Oliver, and descends through a journey of self-exploration and passion. Guadagnino gave a superb representation of internal conflict and feelings of individuals experiencing "queer" or "gay" feelings/preferences as well as their tendency to isolate themselves. Over generations, there has been a huge increase in support of the LGBTQ community, but in the 80's, where the film takes place, the subject of acceptance and discussions of LGBTQ individuals was still fragile and sensitive/touchy in society.

    Throughout the film, there is little attention or judgement posed on Elio and Oliver due to their numerous choices of isolation. Due to this, the two characters are never caught in public nor shamed for their actions. There is a scene where they are roaming the streets of Italy with excitement and exuberant acts of affection where the camera catches them at medium shots and long shots, quickly panning along in unison with their movements and slowly focusing in as they get closer. These swift shots allow the viewer to feel their sense of risk as well as true passion towards each other. They knew it was deemed "wrong" in their community, but took the risk anyway. In the 80's, displaying affection with the same sex in public was rarely attempted due to the responses it received. This resulted in these impulsive acts, revealing their longing for comfort and freedom in society, which was a common feeling felt with other queer/gay individuals.

    Also, Elio's internal conflict was expressed several times throughout the film, and was emphasized to an even greater extent in the classic closing scene. In the closing scene, Elio is seen walking into the dining room of his home, where the table is filled with decorations and being prepared for dinner. He makes his way over to the burning fire, kneels down and expresses a deep, long gaze, exploring his own internal feelings. The camera displays a racking focus, switching our attention from his outside surroundings, and solely on him, almost as if he is in his own head internalizing the song playing. The song, "Is it A Video" plays, starting off at a depressive, low pitch state, and coming to an eventual high pitch climax, which mirrored his own facial expressions. His face started off with tears and sadness, and ending in acceptance of his situation and a smile. The sonic texture of the music paired with the focusing shot, successfully allowed the viewer to visualize not only the internal conflict and mental distress he is experiencing, but what so many other queer/gay individuals are experiencing as well. Having to accept the fact that they could not love who they wanted was common and deemed unhealthy mentally. To conclude, I feel as though this film displayed a perfect interpretation of queer/gay individuals during this time period and in this location.

After spending this summer in Europe, this film transported me right back. The brilliant cinematography captured the essence of their lives and of the world around them, making the scenery almost tangible to the audience. I did notice some visually choppy moments, but in the end, it fit the artistic style of the film. 

The directors took a creative turn on a simple classic coming of age love story, but what eventually sold me was their raw journey and the purity of a first love. There was no hiding of the messiness and infatuation of this romance, which in truth, took me some time to come around to, because it did change my stereotypical and archetypal love story. I felt that melancholic ending to my core and know that I will hold on to this movie for a long time.

Call Me Maybe:

Call Me By Your Name received a lot of buzz with many calling it a modern love masterpiece. The visually stunning film with robust colors and eye gripping scene design stands at the top of the cinematographic pedestal. The film doesn't jump out at you with brilliance, but as the plot crawls along, it fills you with a sense of warmth few movies ever give. 

Call Me By Your Name is set in Italy in 1983. Elio, a 17-year-old homosexual struggling with a sense of self and identity in a time when society suppressed all non-heteronormative thoughts. His father's intern, Oliver a 24-year-old American Ph.D. student, is also homosexual but due to society often engages with women. Elio does more than hint at his infatuation for the American, but throughout the film we see him struggle with acceptance of his feelings. 

Elio is entirely dependent on his parents and is blooming into adulthood, but he's certainly not there yet making the true love story clash a bit. The film pins Elio's coming of age entirely on his sexuality throughout, spending nearly a quarter of the film in incredibly sexual situations. The vivid depiction of his young teenage lust is slathered throughout the unlikely love story in ways that most viewers don't expect.   

To say the film is long-winded is an understatement. Call Me By Your Name spares no scene in telling a relatively slow coming of age true love story. Italian director Luca Guadagnino allows the viewer to stroll at their own pace through the 132-minute plot and not miss a beat. A lot of scenes almost feel unnecessary as we see so little character development outside of sex. The archetypal true love story is questionable while one's primal instincts are flashing red as a seemingly statutory relationship is made believable. 

The setting of the film has almost nothing to do with the plot as a challenging topic of homosexuality in the '80s is made to seem culturally accepted. The only opposition the two characters see is their self-doubt as no one seems to question their involvement. Because of this, the paradise world of acceptance makes the film hard to engage with and inaccurately represents the struggles the gay community has and does face. I think Moonlight got this part right as the characters were more relatable through hardships and not their mental urges being suppressed by a theoretical cultural opposition.  

The film itself is well written and visually perfect. and I would recommend it to others. But, the development is lackluster and the pacing is somewhat wasteful as viewers are on the hook for more than two hours for a relatively simple resolution. I give Call Me By Your Name 3 out of 5 stars. It doesn't blow you away, but you can't help but smile to see young love be affirmed when society opposes it. The most important aspect is it's not your typical true love story yet audiences still identify with it very strongly. This speaks to how far we've come as a society.

What can be salvaged from Call Me by Your Name is the hope that a great book was spoiled by the ineptitude of major motion picture producers. Otherwise, one is left with the burning feeling that there really may be a great disconnect between what they and others consider great art. And this burning feeling is only supplemented by the fear that others might betray their own feelings and project approval on works of art that they think they are supposed to like because of whatever societal narrative is thrown down their throats. Yes, I do really fear that the reason why Call Me by Your Name received such high acclaim is because of its message and not its craft.
	Because if you were really entertained during the vast majority of that film, then your standards for entertainment are very sad indeed. So long as a production has Timothee Chalamat's face, idyllic Italian landscapes, and music then you are to be satisfied. For it was made quite clear that other factors were nowhere near the top of the priority list for the filmmakers. Character development was vested totally in two characters both of whom the filmmakers reasoned shouldn't really experience too much transformation because Gd forbid that might make them the least bit interesting. 
	While the depiction of a young gay couple should seemingly be good for representation purposes, the connotations brought about by the film's depiction of this couple are obviously problematic. Firstly, Elio is no older than seventeen and while he shows no hesitation in hooking up with his father's research assistant, one would hope the man who appears at the very least ten years Elio's senior would show some prudence. Oliver seems to be far more concerned with his own satisfaction than the effects of his actions on an obviously innocent Elio, a character shown to be a clear novice in exploring his sexuality. Nonetheless, Oliver persists and the juxtaposition of his sterling frame breeds all the more worry in the viewer as he watches Elio try to keep up. 
	The film hyper focuses on Elio and attempts to get away with little suspense, little plot-driven excitement, and much confusion. The producers muddied this film with depictions rather than narratives. Instead of captivating the audience with stories and scenes, they merely showed landscapes, people, and moments. While these small glimpses into the lives of characters are vital in films, they lose their charm when the film becomes a composite of small talk and meaningless interaction which contributes to no larger narrative. 
	Nearing the end of Charlie Kaufman's Adaptation, McKee says, "I'll tell you a secret. The last act makes a film. Wow them in the end, and you got a hit. You can have flaws, problems, but wow them in the end, and you've got a hit." Call Me by Your Name had flaws, problems, and still, almost got out scott-free with an ending that would make McKee beam with pride. The mundaneness of the first two hours gave the ending a particular leeway to shine. And shine it did. Unexpectedly, Elio's father delivers a monologue reminiscent of Robin Williams' famous park scene in Good Will Hunting. It is an impassioned speech of acceptance. Coupled with an ending scene in which Sufjan Stevens' chords could drive angels to speech, Call Me by Your Name submitted a farewell that almost made me excuse the past two hours of misery.

The experience of young love can be difficult to portray on screen as it can easily feel false and condescending when brought to life by adult men. This film does not make the mistakes of Flipped (2010) or Angus, Thongs and Perfect Snogging (2008) and treats it's characters and their concerns seriously even if they are rather juvenile. It serves as more of a love letter to youth and the passions that consume you than anything and we are swept up in the emotions and the excitement of the young lovers we are so enchanted by and we are utterly devastated when they are separated.

Somewhere in Italy in 1983 seventeen year old Elio Perlman, Timothée Chalamet, falls in love with his father's protégé Oliver, Armie Hammer, over the summer. He initially struggles with his own feelings and chooses to willfully ignore and disrespect him so he will not be hurt. The two eventually admit their feelings for one another and consummate their relationship but affairs are complicated by Perlman's relationship with Marzia, Esther Garrel, and Oliver's ambivalence about entering into a heterosexual relationship. The two fall in love completely but Oliver leaves and Perlman must deal with moving on from his first real love.

Director Luca Guadagnino is well known for his ability to make his audiences understand not only the visual senses but also be able to taste the fresh peas that the characters consume and smell the dewy grass that they lie in. I couldn't tell you exactly what it is that he does but you do feel familiar with the locations that he films in by at least the midpoint of the film and small moments dropped in between scenes that advance the plot inform you of the location and the way that people live their everyday lives. Films should be able to make you feel something and this film not only makes you care for it's characters but also the world they inhabit as you feel quite an affection for this little Italian town by the end of the film.

The love story itself is richly developed as the film makes the deliberate decision to move slowly and show the attraction between it's two leads building up. The repressed sexual tension could initially come off as anger towards one another but then we discover that the two are in fact extremely drawn to each other and we feel overjoyed when Oliver finally agrees to physically engage with the moody Perlman. When we see the two of them together they do not seem overly idealized as we know that they are both afraid of losing the ecstatic happiness they currently feel. This tension is present in all of their movements and when Perlman breaks down we are simultaneously horrified and comforted by the empathetic response of his lover. The screenplay, written by the famed James Ivory, informs our love of these characters as it never seems to rush through their relationship and has a real understanding of what would attract these two to one another in the first place.

The performances add to the beauty of the film as breakout star Timothée Chalamet is subtle and sensitive in the lead role even when we witness him using a peach to pleasure himself. He also has great chemistry with Hammer who is capable of bringing a necessary jocularity and confidence to the role that complements the more intense and artistic Perlman. The supporting cast amaze us with their ability to convey so much in so little time as we really feel for them even as they interrupt the relationship we want to see thrive. Michael Stuhlbarg gives a great turn as Perlman's supportive archaeology professor father with a scene in which he counsels his son after Oliver's departure being one of the most moving in the film. Amira Casar is reflexive and all knowing as the glamorous mother to Perlman while Garrel brings surprising depth to the role of third wheel quickly abandoned in the love triangle between Perlman and Oliver. 

I would have been very happy to see this film receive more awards from the Academy but I don't think that is quite as good as the fabulous Lady Bird (2017).

Thoughts on ‘Call Me By Your Name'

A story about young love; that's how a friend described it to me. I guess that, to a certain extent, it is. Young love. Messy love. Infatuation. Your first love. Conflicting feelings. Feeling certain things for the first time. 
A tightly contained love story, with a steep spiral of feelings up and a sudden crash down.  Before you know it you're caught up in an emotional rollercoaster resulting in the most intense experience of your life. And before you know it you're left with an empty void in the shape of an Oliver (also goes by the name of Elio).

The first thing I noticed about the film was the aesthetic and the feel. I liked the cinematography. The softness of the image. The setting in rural Italy, where teenagers seem to live somewhat secluded lives. Their world feels very small, adding a very cozy element to the world. The little village seems isolated from the troubles in the rest of the world and the likes of social media. A life of wine, cigarettes and loose blouses in hot summer weather.

As the movie progresses and the story unfolds, I begin to realise there's probably not much of a plot. Everything about this film feels very slice of life. It allows you to take your time watching the scenes, the characters, and to take in the music and sounds very well.
	Eventually the love story unfolds. I don't have much to say about it. It's a slice of life. The story arc is not the main focus. You just watch. So I watch the characters.
I don't know what the writer intended for you to think of Elio and Oliver, or what most people think of them. I don't like them.

Elio. It feels to me like he has no regard for Marzia's feelings. Maybe even like he's using her. He's very caught up in his own feelings. He's young, stupid, conflicted and very much in love (the latter which I only truly grasped towards the end of the film). 
It's understandable. But still. I can't not think of it while watching the main story unfold. It withholds me from getting immersed in Elio's character and the love story. He is either extremely naive when it comes to what his behaviour might do to Marzia, or is aware of what he's inevitably doing to her, but refuses to acknowledge and process those thoughts. 
He's in love. She's in love. You'd guess he'd have the theory of mind ability to place himself in her shoes, especially since he now knows how intense and important love can be. I guess love makes you blind in more ways than one. Stupid Elio.

Marzia is most definitely best girl. She tells Elio that she loves him. It came as kind of a shock to me, but now that I think about it it kind of fits. I feel like she's not in love with Elio in an infatuation kind of way. She actually loves him. Why, I don't know. She probably has her reasons. Anyway, she tells him she's not mad at him. She communicated her feelings and fears. Elio disregards those feelings and turns her fear into reality. He very explicitly hurts her… and she still loves him and truly wants to be his friend. She's too pure for this world.

Note: Not to say that you can necessarily choose the way you love someone or don't. If you fall for someone and become infatuated and obsessed with that person, it's not like it's a choice. I mean with this that Elio isn't necessarily a worse person than Marzia. Although his actions regarding Marzia are hard to look past and ignore. I'm saying Marzia is the more likeable person. (because I judge people based on their actions?)

	I felt neutral towards Oliver in the beginning. He's not my type of guy, but I also didn't dislike him. He kept to himself. I warmed up to him when Elio and him got together and he showed his sensitive and understanding side. I'm not sure how I feel about the phone call at the end. I feel like Elio was being very sexual by saying whispering, almost moaning, his name over and over again. Oliver's breathing increased. That's not something your fiancee is gonna like.

I'm not sure what to make of the monologue by Elio's dad at the end. I feel like he captures the essence of the movie. Feeling your feelings. Don't put them away, don't wish you never had them. I'm not sure what he meant by: most people go bankrupt by 30. 

Your heart is worn out and people don't look at your body anymore. 

He himself has never experienced that. He came close. Does he mean love? Or a love story? An infatuation love story. Like I wanted with her. Maybe.

Thoughts on ‘Call Me By Your Name'

A story about young love; that's how a friend described it to me. I guess that, to a certain extent, it is. Young love. Messy love. Infatuation. Your first love. Conflicting feelings. Feeling certain things for the first time. 
A tightly contained love story, with a steep spiral of feelings up and a sudden crash down.  Before you know it you're caught up in an emotional rollercoaster resulting in the most intense experience of your life. And before you know it you're left with an empty void in the shape of an Oliver (also goes by the name of Elio).

The first thing I noticed about the film was the aesthetic and the feel. I liked the cinematography. The softness of the image. The setting in rural Italy, where teenagers seem to live somewhat secluded lives. Their world feels very small, adding a very cozy element to the world. The little village seems isolated from the troubles in the rest of the world and the likes of social media. A life of wine, cigarettes and loose blouses in hot summer weather.

As the movie progresses and the story unfolds, I begin to realise there's probably not much of a plot. Everything about this film feels very slice of life. It allows you to take your time watching the scenes, the characters, and to take in the music and sounds very well.
	Eventually the love story unfolds. I don't have much to say about it. It's a slice of life. The story arc is not the main focus. You just watch. So I watch the characters.
I don't know what the writer intended for you to think of Elio and Oliver, or what most people think of them. I don't like them.

Elio. It feels to me like he has no regard for Marzia's feelings. Maybe even like he's using her. He's very caught up in his own feelings. He's young, stupid, conflicted and very much in love (the latter which I only truly grasped towards the end of the film). 
It's understandable. But still. I can't not think of it while watching the main story unfold. It withholds me from getting immersed in Elio's character and the love story. If you're a straight man, it'd be easy to think that you're not the target audience here and that taking a rain check is the obvious choice, but honestly, you'd be missing out. Yes, there are a few scenes that some might find a little uncomfortable to watch, but for the most part, 'Call Me By Your Name' is a subtle, nostalgic and poetic exploration of the feelings revolving around your first true love, all set in a visually pleasing, atmospheric and beautifully shot location. It's also outstandingly well-acted, which is particularly important for a film like this where so much is communicated through means other than words or straight-forward statements.

It does take its time poring over the complex situation and all the emotions involved within, and that makes perfect sense from a story and character perspective -- I'd go as far as to say that it's huge part of the appeal -- but that could lead to it feeling a bit slow for some.

Personally, I found myself touched and impressed at the number of feelings that it managed to capture, but most of all for the feeling of nostalgia that it evoked because, regardless of gender or sexual orientation, we've all, at some point or another, experienced the raw emotions on display here.
The story of first love, hard realizations, and inevitable heartache. The very ending scene feels too nostalgic to hold back the tears.

Captured in a human scope with the landscapes of Italy as the backdrop.

Call Me by Your Name is a visually striking piece driven by all the quiet section in this almost 2 and a half hours long movies. 

I can imagine that every other review you've seen on this movie already talked about the amazing story between Elio an Oliver. I would like to focus on the visual aspects of this masterpiece.

Starting with the colour pallet. It's easy to miss the important part that colour makes. The happy and uplifting parts of the movie are all set in bright, yellow to blue-ish colours that are straight out of a dream - which it is.

At the end of the movie, many months after the relationship between the two main characters, all of the scenes are set in dark environment - mostly in darkly lit parts of the room or with dark-ish colour set - dark blue / grey / black.

I love that. Being able to tell the feeling of the main character just from seeing his clothes and the room he's sitting at is awesome and really clever.

Obviously the story is really good. I don't personally find it too long, yeah, it has a lot of quiet parts, but that really emphasis on the feeling behind Eliot's and Oliver's relationship.

Personally I can not find a flaw with this film. The story, the visuals, the dialogue and the passion behind Luca Guadagnino's project are all so incredibly apparent the second that the opening shot happens. Perhaps the only flaw with this film is that we don't get to see what happens to Elio Perlman after the events he goes through with his first real love. Guadagnino is one of the rare directors where his passion shines through in every shot, perfectly portraying Elio's feelings almost as perfectly as Andre Acinan's original novel does, only missing the tiny intimate and personal touches that can only be pulled off through spoken word. Personally I have never seen such an accurate portrayal of queer love and representation in a film, it fills me with such pride to be able to see films like this be nominated for 3 major academy awards including best picture? I have never been so happy to have my heart broken in my life.

Set in the early 1980s, Call Me By Your Name is a coming of age movie where a teenage  boy become infatuated with a handsome visitor who is staying with his academic parents at their home in Italy. In some ways, not a great deal happens. We see a summer romance grow from flirtatious glances and stolen moments, become a sexual exploration and then end. In many ways, it is all quite innocent and yet also quite profound. The atmosphere created is highly aesthetic and somewhat inaccessible with many slow, languorous moments where we witness discussions of ancient history and culture. In some ways, the family seems distant, almost cold which contrast with the hot and sweaty setting of rural Italy. The handsome visitor, Oliver, played by Armie Hammer, is an idealised vision of a mysterious lover who awakens the desires of the young Elio (Timothée Chalamet) who is experimenting with his sexuality. Director Luca Guadagnino makes good use of the beautiful backdrop with many scenes set bicycling through the parched Italian countryside. My only gripe is I wasn't totally convinced by the relationship between Elio and his academic parents which at times seemed to me to be artificially high-brow. I'm not sure it was totally believable as they seemed simultaneously unaware of what was going on and yet totally complicit in their son's burgeoning sexuality and adulthood.
Heartbreaking and poignant.  Well acted with a great song from Sufjan Stevens but it's biggest flaw is that meanders too much.
sensual Italian summer

Better than expected. 

Italy, 1983.  Elio, the 17-year-old son of an academic finds himself attracted to his father's research assistant, Oliver.

I was expecting this to be your usual schmaltzy, predictable romantic drama, just with a same-sex couple.  However, it is better than that.  

The scene-setting and plot development are good and the characters engaging.  There's a nice ebb and flow to the build-up to the relationship.  Great scenery and cinematography too.

Unfortunately, the groundwork is negated to an extent by the last third or so of the movie, where it does become a fairly standard romantic drama.  The conclusion is not overly profound nor original either.

Overall, watchable but it seemed headed for something more powerful and profound.
Loved it. The score and the aesthetic is just fantastic. The acting and story is sad but at the same time happy.

This movie has impacted me so much, the movie was so profound for me. The story, the layers in the actors performances was just so captivating it draws you in and makes you feel apart of this amazing coming of age story. It opened a wound inside me that made me feel these feelings that I hid deep down for being ashamed of liking men at the time, mostly because I was conditioned by my extremely religious parent. I cried so hard like if I had lost a loved one and Yes the movie was very impactful/deep but who knew the reason it hurt so much was me seeing through a mirror how I was feeling through this film. Definitely a 10/10 would recommend from me!
